name: o-bromotoluene
source: Dreisbach R. R. Physical Properties of Chemical Compounds; Vol. I; American Chemical Society; Washington; 1955.

name: o-bromotoluene
source: Dreisbach R. R. Physical Properties of Chemical Compounds; Vol. I; American Chemical Society; Washington; 1955.
Reason: The compound o-bromotoluene consists of a benzene ring with a methyl group and bromine atom attached on adjacent carbons. - Basic unit, benzene has a melting point of 5.5°C. - Methyl group: -5°C (generally makes the compound more hydrophobic and may slightly decrease the melting point due to branched structures tending to pack less efficiently in the solid state). - Bromine atom: +50°C (heavier halogens tend to substantially increase the melting point due to the increase in van der Waals forces provided by the larger, more polarizable electron cloud of bromine). The combined effects are predicted to be a melting point higher than benzene.

name: o-bromotoluene
source: Dreisbach R. R. Physical Properties of Chemical Compounds; Vol. I; American Chemical Society; Washington; 1955.
Reason: The compound o-bromotoluene consists of a benzene ring with a methyl group and a bromine atom attached on adjacent carbons. - Basic unit, benzene has a melting point of 5.5°C. - Methyl group: -5°C (generally makes the compound more hydrophobic and may slightly decrease the melting point due to branched structures tending to pack less efficiently in the solid state). - Bromine atom: -20°C (although bromine is a larger, more polarizable atom which could increase the melting point, in this case, its position ortho to the methyl group might hinder the crystalline packing, leading to a lower melting point). The combination of these effects suggests a melting point that is slightly lower than that of benzene.
